Profile: dev

The dev profile is the recommended default for software work: it layers more tools and delegation agents on top of a base setup so the assistant can both reason and act.

What it’s optimized for

  • Repo exploration and explanation
  • Editing and iteration (generate → run → fix)
  • Structured work via specialist agents (design, debugging, research, implementation)

Expected ingredients (conceptual)

  • Base tools: filesystem + bash
  • Internet-enabled tools (depending on configuration): web + search
  • Tasking: a “task” tool/module for multi-step workflows
  • Specialist agents: e.g. zen-architect, bug-hunter, researcher, modular-builder, explorer
  • UI hooks: often includes streaming UI and logging hooks
Security posture
dev tends to be more powerful. More tools/modules means more ways to touch your system and network—great for productivity, but you should understand what’s enabled.

Tradeoffs

  • More complexity: when something goes wrong, there are more modules in the chain
  • More variability: behavior can differ based on active tools, hooks, and installed collections

When to switch away

  • Use base if you want fewer integrations.
  • Use test if you want a focused testing workflow.
  • Use foundation if you’re debugging configuration or want minimal tool access.
